text: I can think of a few options for things that might cause this, and have some ideas for parsing them out:

elements.text: I can think of a few options for things that might cause this, and have some ideas for parsing them out:

text: I woud check whether this is an issue with the blending or with the raw data in DF mode. To check, I would do a test with a smaller Z stack (but large enough to see the waviness) and get all of the raw DF data. In that raw data I would check whether it looks crisp or not at the places where you see waviness in the processed data. If not, then the issue is the processing algorithm, which is a black box. If you do see waviness, the culprit is likely that the location of the horizontal focus that the DF is assuming, is mismatched to the actual horizontal focus position. I have seen this issue before, particularly if you are using short exposures with the DF (say, below 100ms) and I have the feeling LaVision has improved on it. But perhaps it is still not solved.

elements.text: I woud check whether this is an issue with the blending or with the raw data in DF mode. To check, I would do a test with a smaller Z stack (but large enough to see the waviness) and get all of the raw DF data. In that raw data I would check whether it looks crisp or not at the places where you see waviness in the processed data. If not, then the issue is the processing algorithm, which is a black box. If you do see waviness, the culprit is likely that the location of the horizontal focus that the DF is assuming, is mismatched to the actual horizontal focus position. I have seen this issue before, particularly if you are using short exposures with the DF (say, below 100ms) and I have the feeling LaVision has improved on it. But perhaps it is still not solved.

text: The other possible issue that could be causing some of this is that the Z drive on this device is not perfectly straight. This is something that Nico Renier and Christoph Kirst go into in extreme detail in their tour-de-force vasculature mapping paper (<https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/32059781/>). The whole idea of their "Wobbly stitcher" is to compensate for the wobbles they see in XY, when moving in Z. My suspicion is that this is not the main culprit for what you see in your data, but could contribute on the margins.

attachments.title: Mapping the Fine-Scale Organization and Plasticity of the Brain Vasculature - PubMed
attachments.text: The cerebral vasculature is a dense network of arteries, capillaries, and veins. Quantifying variations of the vascular organization across individuals, brain regions, or disease models is challenging. We used immunolabeling and tissue clearing to image the vascular network of adult mouse brains and â€¦
attachments.fallback: PubMed: Mapping the Fine-Scale Organization and Plasticity of the Brain Vasculature - PubMed

elements.text: The other possible issue that could be causing some of this is that the Z drive on this device is not perfectly straight. This is something that Nico Renier and Christoph Kirst go into in extreme detail in their tour-de-force vasculature mapping paper (

). The whole idea of their "Wobbly stitcher" is to compensate for the wobbles they see in XY, when moving in Z. My suspicion is that this is not the main culprit for what you see in your data, but could contribute on the margins.

text: In short, my suggestion would be to get the raw DF data, compare to the processed, and look very carefully at whether the horizontal focus seems like it is where it should be, and whether the problems only show up after the blending process.

elements.text: In short, my suggestion would be to get the raw DF data, compare to the processed, and look very carefully at whether the horizontal focus seems like it is where it should be, and whether the problems only show up after the blending process.

text: Happy to chat more over the phone/zoom with screensharing to look at the data in more detail, if that would help.

elements.text: Happy to chat more over the phone/zoom with screensharing to look at the data in more detail, if that would help.

text: And apologies if all my suggestions are super obvious and you've already tried them.

elements.text: And apologies if all my suggestions are super obvious and you've already tried them.

text: Hi Pablo, I am curious how to access the raw data from a DF focus capture. How can this be done?

elements.text: Hi Pablo, I am curious how to access the raw data from a DF focus capture. How can this be done?

text: In Autosave settings, in the advanced options there is something that allows you to save the raw data. When you engage that option you will get both the processed data AND the raw images. Beware that for dynamic focus that typically involves an order of magnitude more data, given that 10-20 positions are not unheard of for high NA and low mag. If I recall correctly, the way the data is structured is as a stack for each Z position, where each image in the stack is a different horizontal focus position. If you had a high NA, sweeping across you should be able to "see" where the location of max focus is, which will in turn give you a clue (even in this strictly XY view) as to whether the horizontal focus is in the position that the system thinks it is.

elements.text: In Autosave settings, in the advanced options there is something that allows you to save the raw data. When you engage that option you will get both the processed data AND the raw images. Beware that for dynamic focus that typically involves an order of magnitude more data, given that 10-20 positions are not unheard of for high NA and low mag. If I recall correctly, the way the data is structured is as a stack for each Z position, where each image in the stack is a different horizontal focus position. If you had a high NA, sweeping across you should be able to "see" where the location of max focus is, which will in turn give you a clue (even in this strictly XY view) as to whether the horizontal focus is in the position that the system thinks it is.

text:
Hi Sam, my experience unfortunately with the DF is not very positive; are more the times I see strange artefacts, then when is working. I haven`t well characterized the issue,s but, currently I basically never use it. Maybe also this comment is obvious, but I m learning that because a perfect alignment of the 3 sheets is very hard, the 3 shees don`t equally cover the focal plane,
for the DF is better to use just the central one. Also, I was actually impressed that in the paper that Ariel mentioned, the don`t use the DF (!!), but they use a crazy number of tiles using a dramatically cropped chip..I ll let you know if I`ll see your "waves" and I find some solution

elements.text:
Hi Sam, my experience unfortunately with the DF is not very positive; are more the times I see strange artefacts, then when is working. I haven`t well characterized the issue,s but, currently I basically never use it. Maybe also this comment is obvious, but I m learning that because a perfect alignment of the 3 sheets is very hard, the 3 shees don`t equally cover the focal plane,
for the DF is better to use just the central one. Also, I was actually impressed that in the paper that Ariel mentioned, the don`t use the DF (!!), but they use a crazy number of tiles using a dramatically cropped chip..I ll let you know if I`ll see your "waves" and I find some solution

text: Hey Pablo, thank you! I will give this a try when i have a moment to troubleshoot and report back,

text: We do use low exposure times usually, but not that low, hovering around 120-180ms when using DF

text: No, these are very helpful, thakn you for sharing. I am going to take a stab at your suggestions, and if I am still not seeing a differene will get in touch down the road. Thank you!

elements.text: No, these are very helpful, thakn you for sharing. I am going to take a stab at your suggestions, and if I am still not seeing a differene will get in touch down the road. Thank you!

text: Thanks for the input Alessandro! We generally avoid DF and also used a cropped field of view, but if DF did work as advertised its very seductive. So i have been trying to get it to work as well as possible, even though for our actual experimental tissue we try to avoid it.
